rComments: Very unorganized and doesn’t lecture, but instead tells stories. Had him for 3 classes and didn’t learn one useful thing. But I heard him whine about being laid off a few dozen times. Doesn’t grade/return assignments until about the last week of class. Grades are based on his opinions rather than an actual rubric. I don’t recommend this teacher.

Wessman loves video games which is cool. However, his lack of programming/teaching skills makes him poor teacher. Lectures were mostly story + audience responses. If you want to progress as a programmer and game developer, I would avoid if possible.

Professor Wessman was a blast to learn from. His lectures were relevant and fun, and his assignment were very reflective of tasks one might do in the real games industry. I really appreciated the effort he put in to have companies come to classes and share their experience with us, and giving us an opportunity to apply right there. Great teacher!

His lectures are extremely practical,interesting and fun. Each lecture we learned more about what the game industry is really like. He had great advice when issues arose, and I found his worksheets very useful for anyone designing a game. His passion for games and student success exceeds his lack of organization and chaotic teaching structure.

Wessman was easily the best game design professor I have ever had. Even tho he can be disorganized with class work, he makes up for it with his passion for his students to succeed. When I am brainstorming a new game, I go back to Wessman's worksheets, which are an invaluable method for planning a successful project.

Although he can be disorganized at times, Professor Wessman makes up for it with the quality of the work he assigns. In the middle of the class, some of the work can seem pointless, but looking back I can see the value in all the assignments he gave. On top of that, he's extremely helpful outside of class and friendly too! I'd take his class again.

Nice guy. Passionate about what he is doing. Stickler for schedules and worksheet details, but he's trying to create a real work environment where mistakes might be unforgiving. Overall, a good professor.

David was one of my favorite teachers at UCSC, He is very passionate about making video games and has plenty of experience within the industry. He talks about his experiences which give you an insight of how the industry works. He is also always willing to help any student that approaches him and he trys his best to help his students out and learn

How anyone rates David less than a 5 in helpfulness probably never asked for help. He was probably one of the most dedicated professors I've ever had. He would let students borrow his personal copies of games, textbooks, and reference books if you needed inspiration.

David is the best game design teacher I've had, by far.  Game design and the entire process from pre-production to publication is something that his wisdom is immensely valuable.  Just come into his class with programming skills already, because he isn't much help there.  As far as game (not computer science stuff) goes, he is unmatched.

David's approach to teaching is very "hands off" meaning that he will give you general guiding anecdotes and resources, but will not try to push you in a certain direction. Thus, talking to him directly was more valuable than attending lecture, which may be a good thing for some but not for others.

Brought great insight to the major as he has a large amount of industry experience, something other teachers cannot replicate.  This gives him a different angle on game design compared to the rest of the campus.  Lectures are funny and his stories feel real and applicable (useful lessons to be learned).

He's perfect for students that ask questions and let him know what will help them learn. Very knowledgeable about the realities of the field and will prepare you. It'd be nice if he were better prepared, but he'll see reason if he messed up. Most constructive and approachable design professor I've had at this school by far. Really cares.

Very experienced designer in the games industry, his input was absolutely invaluable to our project. I honestly do not believe that any other professor would have helped us see our game through to its finish as well as he did.

Having David again for the second time in the senior sequence was upsetting. He was never prepared with lecture plans, posted all of the assignments last minute, never gave a formal syllabus, never gave feedback on "critical" assignments and didn't help progress our game at all. He is obviously passionate about game design but completely unfocused.

David was rarely prepared for any lecture. I can't think of a single thing that I learned from him specifically, though he is a nice guy. I liked his stories of the industry but this almost never gave better insight on how to design better games. The games ideas that came out of the class could have been a lot better if David was more engaged.

Does not really explain how he grades things or what exactly he wants which leads to hard grading and confusion. But all in all gives good real world experience and deadlines to make you better prepared.
Not the best "teacher" per say but he will get you used to real world experience and deadlines.
At the beginning of the class David was a bit unorganized, but as the quarter went on he got his skills together. He has the best stories and real world experience, you can't replace that.

Wessman has a great amount of experience throughout his years in the game design industry. This translates to some very interesting stories and useful information. The worksheets are a typical complaint but easy to do given you quickly knock them out with your team. I enjoyed my two quarters with Wessman overall. Just be aware of your deadlines.

He will get behind on grading, and he doesn't plan his lectures very well, but there is a ton of value to listening to his stories and experience. He's extremely approachable and cares a lot about his students. He expects people to do their work and actually put effort into it. As long as you don't BS your work, doing well in the class is easy.
Very inefficient, didn't give any grades until the last week.  Very political and subjective with grading and judging. Would not recommended.
Wessman has great industry experience to share and help us learn from. I would take another class with him anytime.

The professor is pretty disorganized. Class was very confusing, grading seemed unfair half the time, and nothing technical was taught during class. He is super slow at grading and we did not get our grades until the start of the next quarter. There were few good things about the class such as input on the gaming industy and working on the project.

Wessman is so impossibly incompetent that I honestly believe his class would have been better taught if he had just never shown up to teach at all. He never plans his lectures, teaches little to no relevant information, and throws meaningless hard deadlines at students with only hours notice. The fact that he's still teaching is an insult to UCSC.

He has some interesting stories, but that's about it. He's horribly disorganized and doesn't give any real feedback on work turned in, even though it takes him about four weeks minimum to get anything back to you.
The midterm grade was not shown up even when the course is over. You won't learn any technical stuff but a lot of his view of industrial stories.

He was very behind on grading (~5 weeks) and didn't mention coding at all or teach it. If you do the assignment perfectly he gives an A- because for an A you have to go beyond what he tells you to do.
He works you really hard, but he is the greatest game design teacher I've had.  It was a great experience working with him.

What others have said concerning the lack of organization and clarity around assignments is true. However, this is because his teaching style is not really suited to traditional "lecture" settings; he is very much a hands on teacher. As such, a lot of what you get out of the course depends on what you put in. Overall he is  a good teacher.
Where to start... too much industry story, too little content, and an insane amount of GDC videos.

Professor Wessman is easily the best game design professor I have had at UCSC. The only down side is that he is very disorganized, which can lead to confusion on due dates for assignments. On the other hand, he is very fair about grading. That aside, he also has tons of real life knowledge about game design, and he is more than happy to share!

Wessman does not plan his lectures. He tells stories instead of lecturing, and ends up frequently wasting class time. He is very disorganized, he often posted assignments just hours before they were due, and didn't return any graded work until week 10. Most of his difficulty comes from having to navigate his disorganization and vague expectations.

I registered this class hoping to learn something and create actual game. David will not actually teach you real thing but fill in his lack by random guest lecture. He even miss the test! Prepare to learn everything yourself. Recommend for anyone loves to hear 'bedtime' stories.

David likes to fill the bulk of class time by telling random stories of his industry days, at the expense of anything resembling an actual curriculum. He then turns around and tests us on his inane stories, having no other material to test on. Couldn't care less about his talent as a game designer, he couldn't teach his way out of a wet paper bag.
David is a speech man rather than a teacher. He doesn't plan anything before going to class so student might be surprised with random, uncleared assignments. Faculty should audit his lectures.
